I shall convey you all to my house  in Berkeley Street and we shall taste  all the delights of the season--what  say you?
Oh, please can I go? I'm twelve soon.
Mr Palmer, do you not long to have  the Misses Dashwood come to London?
I came into Devonshire with no other  view.
ELINOR exerts herself.
Mrs Jennings, you are very kind, but  we cannot possibly leave our mother...
LUCY's calculating eyes turn to MRS DASHWOOD with alacrit
Indeed, the loss would be too great.
A chorus of objections goes up, particularly from MRS  DASHWOOD, who is both delighted and relieved to see MARIA with a smile on her face.
Your mother can spare you very well.
Of course I can!
Of course she can!
And look at Miss Marianne--it would  break her heart to deny her!
I will brook no refusal, Miss  Dashwood!
MARIANNE claps her hands, her eyes ablaze with joy. MRS  JENNINGS takes ELINOR's hand.
Let you and me strike hands upon the  bargain--and if I do not have the  three of you married by Christmas,  it will not be my fault!

We are in ELINOR and MARIANNE's bedroom. ELINOR is in bed She is lying on her side with her back to MARIANNE. We ar CLOSE on her face. MARIANNE is running around excitedly,  pulling out ribbons, looking at dresses, etc.

I was never so grateful in all my  life as I am to Mrs Jennings. What a  kind woman she is! I like her more  than I can say. Oh, Elinor! I shall  see Willoughby. Think how surprised  he will be! And you will see Edward!
ELINOR cannot reply.
Are you asleep?
With you in the room?
MARIANNE laughs.
I do not believe you feel as calm as  you look, not even you, Elinor. I  will never sleep tonight! Oh, what  were you and Miss Steele whispering  about so long?
CLOSE on ELINOR's expression as she struggles with the  impossibility of unburdening herself to her sister withou breaking her promise to LUCY. After a pause--
Nothing of significance.
MARIANNE looks at ELINOR curiously, then returns to her  packing.
MRS DASHWOOD and MARGARET are waving MRS JENNINGS's carri off. MARIANNE waves back with such exuberance that she  practically falls out.
MRS JENNINGS is chattering about London to MARIANNE, who  listens with new-found tolerance. LUCY is whispering into ELINOR's ear.
I have written to Edward, Miss  Dashwood, and yet I do not know how  much I may see of him. Secrecy is  vital--he will never be able to call.
I should imagine not.
It is so hard. I believe my only  comfort has been the constancy of  his affection.
You are fortunate, over such a lengthy  engagement, never to have had any  doubts on that score.
LUCY looks at ELINOR sharply, but ELINOR is impassive.
Oh! I am of rather a jealous nature  and if he had talked more of one  young lady than any other... but he  has never given a moment's alarm on  that count.
We can see from ELINOR's expression that she understands  LUCY perfectly. The strain around her eyes is pronounced.
Imagine how glad he will be to learn  that we are friends!
MRS JENNINGS's carriage trundles along.
Establishing shot of a handsome town house. MRS JENNINGS' carriage comes into shot and stops in front of it.

They enter the grand hallway under the supercilious gaze a powdered FOOTMAN (MR PIGEON). ELINOR is haggard after t days of close proximity with LUCY. MRS JENNINGS is all  officious bustle and MARIANNE is feverish with anticipati She whispers to MRS JENNINGS, who laughs heartily.
To be sure, my dear, you must just  hand it to Pigeon there. He will  take care of it.
MARIANNE hands a letter to the sphinx-like FOOTMAN. We ca see a large W in the address. ELINOR looks at MARIANNE  inquiringly but MARIANNE moves away from her.
Lord above, you do not waste any  time, Miss Marianne!
MARIANNE glances self-consciously at ELINOR and follows M JENNINGS upstairs. LUCY goes up to ELINOR and whispers.
A letter! So they are definitely  engaged! Mrs Jennings says your sister  will buy her wedding clothes here in  town.
Indeed Miss Steele, I know of no  such plan.
But ELINOR does not know what else to say. She marches fi upstairs.
MARIANNE and ELINOR have changed from their traveling clo and are having a cup of tea. At least, ELINOR is. MARIANN is pacing up and down in front of the window.
John and Fanny are in town. I think  we shall be forced to see them.
There is a faint knocking from somewhere. MARIANNE jumps.
I think it was for next door.
MARIANNE looks out of the window.
Yes, you are right.

She sits down with a rueful smile. Suddenly a much louder rap is heard and they both jump. We hear a bustling  downstairs. MARIANNE can hardly breathe. She goes to the  drawing-room door, opens it, goes out, comes back in. We  hear a MAN's voice.
Oh, Elinor! It is Willoughby, indeed  it is!
She turns and almost throws herself into the arms of COLO BRANDON.
Oh! Excuse me, Colonel--
She leaves the room hastily. ELINOR is so ashamed of  MARIANNE's rudeness that she does not at first notice  BRANDON's mood of tense distress.
Colonel Brandon, what a pleasure to  see you! Have you been in London all  this while?
I have. How is your dear mother?
Very well, thank you.
Silence.
Colonel, is there anything--
But BRANDON interrupts her.

Forgive me, Miss Dashwood, but I  have heard reports through town...  is it impossible to--but I could  have no chance of succeeding--indeed  I hardly know what to do. Tell me  once and for all, is everything  finally resolved between your sister  and Mr Willoughby?
ELINOR is torn between discomfiture and compassion.
Colonel, though neither one has  informed me of their under standing,  I have no doubt of their mutual  affection.
BRANDON stands very still.
Thank you, Miss Dashwood. To your  sister I wish all imaginable  happiness. To Mr Willoughby, that  he... may endeavour to deserve her.
His tone is heavy with some bitter meaning.
What do you mean?
But he recollects himself.
Forgive me, I--forgive me.
He bows and leaves abruptly. ELINOR is deeply troubled.

The PALMERS, MRS JENNINGS, JOHN, FANNY, LUCY, ELINOR and  MARIANNE are walking through the arcade. Additional wealt has evidently encouraged FANNY sartorially and she sprout as much fruit and feathers as a market stall. LUCY is hol ELINOR's arm in a pinionlike grip. MRS JENNINGS is gossip with CHARLOTTE. MARIANNE's good looks are heightened by her feverish  expectation of seeing WILLOUGHBY at every step, and many  young men raise their hats to her and turn as she passes.
Where is dear Edward, John? We expect  to see him daily.
FANNY stiffens. LUCY's sharp eyes dart hither and thither MRS JENNINGS senses gossip. ELINOR steels herself.
And who is 'dear Edward'?
Who indeed?
FANNY smiles glacially.
My brother, Mrs Jennings--Edward  Ferrars.
MRS JENNINGS looks at ELINOR in sly triumph.
Indeed! Is that Ferrars with an F?
She and CHARLOTTE chuckle to each other. LUCY looks at EL
MRS JENNINGS, LUCY, ELINOR and MARIANNE return from their outing. MARIANNE immediately assails PIGEON.
Are there any messages, Pigeon?
No, ma'am.
No message at all? No cards?
(affronted) None, ma am.
MARIANNE sighs with disappointment and starts up the stai MRS JENNINGS looks archly at ELINOR.
I note you do not inquire for your  messages, Miss Dashwood!
No, for I do not expect any, Mrs  Jennings. I have very little  acquaintance in town.
And she follows MARIANNE firmly upstairs. LUCY watches he go, and MRS JENNINGS chuckles and turns to her.
She is as sly as you, Lucy!
ELINOR wakes up. The flickering of a candle has disturbed her. She sits up in bed and sees MARIANNE sitting at the  desk in her nightgown, writing another letter.
Marianne, is anything wrong?
Nothing at all. Go back to sleep.

MARIANNE, in her nightclothes and dressing gown, paces  restlessly, her letter in her hands. A slight knock at th door heralds a much-ruffled PIGEON, wig askew. MARIANNE h him the letter. He bows and goes, highly disgruntled.
MRS JENNINGS is giving PIGEON his instructions for the da MARIANNE comes running downstairs. PIGEON regards her dri
No messages, ma am.
MARIANNE looks so dejected that MRS JENNINGS takes her ha
Do not fret, my dear. I am told that  this good weather is keeping many  sportsmen in the country at present,  but the frost will drive them back  to town very soon, depend upon it.
MARIANNE brightens.
Of course! I had not thought of-- thank you, Mrs Jennings!
She runs back upstairs. MRS JENNINGS calls after her.
And Miss Dashwood may set her heart  at rest, for I overheard your sister- in-law say that she was to bring the  elusive Mr F to the ball tonight!

location: GRAND CRESCENT LEADING TO BALLROOM ENTRANCE

text: So many carriages have entered the crescent to deliver th GUESTS that gridlock has occurred and people are forced t walk to the entrance. We see MRS JENNINGS, MARIANNE, ELIN and LUCY alighting from their carriage and picking their through the mud, their skirts raised above their ankles.  ELINOR nearly trips and is obliged to grab onto LUCY in o not to slip into the dirt.

The great ballroom is crammed with GUESTS all determined enjoy themselves despite the considerable inconveniences  caused by noise, heat and overcrowding. MEN are sweating  profusely, WOMEN dab their brows, rack punch is being  swallowed by the gallon, flirting is conducted at fever p and all conversation is inordinately loud. Only the DANCE have a modicum of space in which to perform their mincing steps. MRS JENNINGS and her brood bump into the PALMERS.
(screeching) This is very merry!
MRS JENNINGS then spots FANNY, who is conducting a desult conversation with an overpowdered ACQUAINTANCE. She drags ELINOR, MARIANNE and LUCY over to her.
There you are! Goodness, how hot it  is, Mrs Dashwood. You are not alone,  I trust?
Indeed not. John is just gone to  fetch my brother--he has been eating  ices.
LUCY clutches at ELINOR's sleeve.
Your brother! I declare, that is  good news indeed. At long last!
And she beams her approval upon ELINOR.
(whispering) Miss Dashwood, I declare I shall  faint clean away.
FANNY has seen JOHN threading his way towards them and wa at him. There is someone behind him. LUCY preens. JOHN bo to them.
Mrs Jennings, may I present my brother- in-law?
He turns to reveal a good-looking young MAN with a vacuou smile.
Mr Robert Ferrars!
My dear ladies--we meet at last!
There is a general bowing and shaking of hands. ELINOR is relieved. LUCY drops a low curtsy.
So you must be the younger brother?  Is Mr Edward not here? Miss Dashwood  here was counting on him!
ROBERT looks ELINOR up and down. He exchanges glances wit FANNY before he speaks.
Oh! He is far too busy for such  gatherings--and has no special  acquaintance here to make his  attendance worthwhile.
MRS JENNINGS looks at ELINOR in puzzlement.
Well, I declare, I do not know what  the young men are about these days-- are they all in hiding?
ELINOR looks down, agonised with embarrassment.
Come, Mr Robert, in the absence of  your brother, you must dance with  our lovely Miss Dashwood!
(not best pleased) It would be my honour.
He turns to LUCY and bows.
And perhaps Miss Steele might consider  reserving the allemande?
LUCY curtsies again. ROBERT escorts a most unwilling ELIN onto the dance floor.
You reside in Devonshire, I b'lieve,  Miss Dashwood?
We do.
In a cottage?
Yes.
I am excessively fond of a cottage.  If I had any money to spare, I should  build one myself.

Luckily for ELINOR the set changes and she is obliged to  turn away from ROBERT. She wheels round to face her new  partner. It is WILLOUGHBY! They both stop dancing and sta at each other aghast. A traffic jam starts and they are f to take hands and resume the steps.
(stiff) How do you do, Miss Dashwood?
ELINOR does not know quite how to respond.
I am well, thank you, Mr Willoughby.
She looks about for MARIANNE, instinctively wanting to ke her away from WILLOUGHBY.
How is your--family?
(cold) We are all extremely well, Mr  Willoughby--thank you for your kind  inquiry.
WILLOUGHBY is shamed into silence. Then he sees MARIANNE. the same moment the music pauses. MARIANNE looks up. In t brief moment of relative quiet, her great cry rings acros the room.
Willoughby!

Everyone turns to look as MARIANNE rushes towards him wit both arms outstretched, her face luminous with joy. As th noise of the room builds again and PEOPLE change their  partners, we are aware that many are surreptitiously watc MARIANNE reaches him but WILLOUGHBY stands with his arms  frozen at his side. MARIANNE gives a little confused laug
Good God, Willoughby! Will you nor  shake hands with me?

WILLOUGHBY looks extremely uncomfortable and glances towa a group of very smart PEOPLE who are watching him closely Central to this group is a SOPHISTICATED WOMAN who frowns him proprietorially. WILLOUGHBY shakes MARIANNE's hand briefly. Behind her, MR JENNINGS is giving an animated commentary to FANNY and JO while LUCY whispers in ROBERT's ear as they go past to jo the set.
(strangled) How do you do, Miss Marianne?
Willoughby, what is the matter? Why  have you not come to see me? Were  you not in London? Have you nor  received my letters?
WILLOUGHBY is sweating with tension.
Yes, I had the pleasure of receiving  the information which you were so  good as to send me.
(piteously) For heaven's sake, Willoughby, tell  me what is wrong!
Thank you--I am most obliged. If you  will excuse me, I must return to my  party.
He bows, white to the teeth, and walks away to join the  SOPHISTICATED WOMAN.
Willoughby!
He is drawn away by his PARTY, some of whom look back at  MARIANNE with a mixture of curiosity and condescension.  MARIANNE almost sinks to her knees. ELINOR supports her.
Marianne! Come away!
Go to him, Elinor--force him to come  to me.
MRS JENNINGS has come up, full of concern.
Dearest, do not betray what you feel  to everyone present! This is not the  place for explanations--
Come along, dear.

They almost have to drag MARIANNE away. MRS JENNINGS turn back to the DASHWOOD party. FANNY and JOHN have practical imploded with embarrassment and are distancing themselves much as possible from the source. LUCY and ROBERT are dan nearby.
Will you come, Lucy?
Oh, are we leaving so soon?
If I might be so bold, Mrs Jennings,  it would be our pleasure to escort  your young charge home.
How very kind!
That is very handsome--
She rushes off to follow MARIANNE and ELINOR. We stay for moment with LUCY and ROBERT who have left the set.
She actually sent him messages during  the night?
CAM rises to show the DASHWOODS exiting past the whisperi sneering faces of the CROWD.
MARIANNE sits scribbling a letter at the desk.
Marianne, please tell me--
Do not ask me questions!
You have no confidence in me.
This reproach from you! You, who  confide in no one.
I have nothing to tell.
Nor I. We have neither of us anything  to tell. I because I conceal nothing  and you because you communicate  nothing.

A silent breakfast. MARIANNE is red-eyed from crying and  limp from lack of sleep. MRS JENNINGS is dressed to go ou pulling on her gloves and bustling as usual. PIGEON enter with a letter on a salver. He offers it to MARIANNE. She  seizes it and runs out of the room. MRS JENNINGS chuckles
There now! Lovers' quarrels are swift  to heal! That letter will do the  trick, mark my word.
She goes to the door.
I must be off. I hope he won't keep  her waiting much longer, Miss  Dashwood. It hurts to see her looking  so forlorn.
She leaves and ELINOR finds herself alone with LUCY, who  loses no time in sharing her new-found happiness.
What a welcome I had from Edward's  family, Miss Dashwood--I am surprised  you never told me what an agreeable  woman your sister-in-law is! And Mr  Robert--all so affable!
It is perhaps fortunate that none of  them knows of your engagement. Excuse  me.
ELINOR rises and leaves.
ELINOR finds MARIANNE sitting on the edge of the bed. She does not acknowledge ELINOR but merely lifts the letter a reads out, with deadly calm:

'My dear Madam--I am quite at a loss  to discover in what point I could be  so unfortunate as to offend you. My  esteem for your family is very sincere  but if I have given rise to a belief  of more than I felt or meant to  express, I shall reproach myself for  not having been more guarded. My  affections have long been engaged  elsewhere and it is with great regret  that I return your letters and the  lock of hair which you so obligingly  bestowed upon me. I am etc. John  Willoughby.'
Oh, Marianne.
MARIANNE gives a great howl of pain and flings herself ac the bed as though in physical agony.

Marianne, oh, Marianne--it is better  to know at once what his intentions  are. Dearest, think of what you would  have felt if your engagement had  carried on for months and months  before he chose to put an end to it.
We are not engaged.
But you wrote to him! I thought then  that he must have left you with some  kind of understanding?
No--he is not so unworthy as you  think him.
Not so unworthy! Did he tell you  that he loved you?
Yes. No--never absolutely. It was  every day implied, but never declared.  Sometimes I thought it had been, but  it never was. He has broken no vow.
He has broken faith with all of us,  he made us all believe he loved you.
He did! He did--he loved me as I  loved him.
MRS JENNINGS bursts through the door in her hat and coat, panting.
I had to come straight up--how are  you, Miss Marianne?
MARIANNE begins to sob uncontrollably.

Poor thing! She looks very bad. No  wonder, Miss Dashwood, for it is but  too true. I was told here in the  street by Miss Morton, who is a great  friend: he is to be married at the  end of the month--to a Miss Grey  with fifty thousand pounds. Well,  said I, if 'tis true, then he is a  good-for-nothing who has used my  young friend abominably ill, and I  wish with all my soul that his wife  may plague his heart out!
She goes round the bed to comfort MARIANNE.
But he is not the only young man  worth having, my dear, and with your  pretty face you will never want for  admirers.
MARIANNE sobs even harder.
Ah, me! She had better have her cry  out and have done with it. I will go  and look out something to tempt her-- does she care for olives?
I cannot tell you.
MRS JENNINGS leaves. MARIANNE seizes the letter again.
I cannot believe his nature capable  of such cruelty!
Marianne, there is no excuse for him-- this is his hand--
But it cannot be his heart! Oh, Mamma!  I want Mamma! Elinor, please take me  home! Cannot we go tomorrow?
There is no one to take us.
Cannot we hire a carriage?
We have no money--and indeed we owe  Mrs Jennings more courtesy.
All she wants is gossip and she only  likes me because I supply it! Oh,  God! I cannot endure to stay.
I will find a way. I promise.
FANNY, JOHN and ROBERT are drinking chocolate together.
Apparently they never were engaged.
Miss Grey has fifty thousand pounds.  Marianne is virtually penniless.

She cannot have expected him to go  through with it. But I feel for  Marianne--she will lose her bloom  and end a spinster like Elinor. I  think, my dear, we might consider  having them to stay with us for a  few days--we are, after all, family,  and my father.
He trails off. FANNY exchanges an alarmed glance with ROB She thinks fast.

My love, I would ask them with all  my heart, but I have already asked  Miss Steele for a visit and we cannot  deprive Mrs Jennings of all her  company at once. We can invite your  sisters some other year, you know,  and Miss Steele will profit far more  from your generosity--poor girl!
That is very thoughtful, Fanny. We  shall ask Elinor and Marianne next  year, then... Certainly!
MRS JENNINGS's carriage stands outside. A livened FOOTMAN opens the door and LUCY steps out brandishing a new muff.

MARIANNE sits alone on the bed. Around her lie her notes Willoughby, her lock of hair and the pocket sonnets. In h hands is the creased and tear-stained letter from Willoug which she is examining over and over.
ELINOR is seated at a desk writing a letter. There is a s rap at the front door. Footsteps are heard and as she tur the maid enters with COLONEL BRANDON. ELINOR rises to gre him.
Thank you for coming, Colonel.
He bows. ELINOR is on edge. BRANDON looks haggard with  concern.
How does your sister?
I must get her home as quickly as  possible. The Palmers can take us as  far as Cleveland, which is but a day  from Barton--
Then permit me to accompany you and  take you straight on from Cleveland  to Barton myself.
ELINOR takes his hands gratefully.
I confess that is precisely what I  had hoped for. Marianne suffers  cruelly, and what pains me most is  how hard she tries to justify Mr  Willoughby. But you know her  disposition.
After a moment BRANDON nods. He seems unable to remain st or calm and finds it difficult to begin speaking.
Perhaps I--my regard for you all-- Miss Dashwood, will you allow me to  prove it by relating some  circumstances which nothing but an  earnest desire of being useful--
You have something to tell me of Mr  Willoughby.

(nods) When I quitted Barton last--but I  must go further back. A short account  of myself will be necessary. No  doubt... no doubt Mrs Jennings has  apprised you of certain events in my  past--the sad outcome of my connection  with a young woman named Eliza.
ELINOR nods.
What is not commonly known is that  twenty years ago, Eliza bore an  illegitimate child. The father,  whoever he was, abandoned them.
This is strong stuff. ELINOR's concern deepens.
As she lay dying, she begged me to  look after the child. Eliza died in  my arms, broken, wasted away--ah!  Miss Dashwood, such a subject-- untouched for so many years--it is  dangerous...
He paces about, barely able to conceal his distress.

I had failed Eliza in every other  way--I could not refuse her now. I  took the child--Beth is her name-- and placed her with a family where I  could be sure she would be well looked  after. I saw her whenever I could. I  saw that she was headstrong like her  mother--and, God forgive me, I  indulged her, I allowed her too much  freedom. Almost a year ago, she  disappeared.
Disappeared!

I instigated a search but for eight  months I was left to imagine the  worst. At last, on the day of the  Delaford picnic, I received the first  news her. She was with child... and  the blackguard who had--
BRANDON stops and looks straight at ELINOR.
Good God. Do you mean--Willoughby?
BRANDON nods. ELINOR drops into a chair, utterly shocked.
Before I could return to confront  him, Lady Allen learned of his  behaviour and turned him from the  house. He beat a hasty retreat to  London--
Yes! He left us that morning, without  any explanation!
Lady Allen had annulled his legacy.  He was left with next to nothing,  and in danger of losing all that  remained to his debtors--
--and so abandoned Marianne for Miss  Grey and her fifty thousand pounds.
BRANDON is silent. ELINOR is breathless.
Have you seen Mr Willoughby since  you learned...?
(nodding) We met by appointment, he to defend,  I to punish his conduct.
ELINOR stares at him, aghast.
We returned unwounded, so the meeting  never got abroad.
ELINOR nods and is silent for a moment.
Is Beth still in town?
She has chosen to go into the country  for her confinement. Such has been  the unhappy resemblance between the  fate of mother and daughter, and so  imperfectly have I discharged my  trust.
A pause.
I would not have burdened you, Miss  Dashwood, had I not from my heart  believed it might, in time, lessen  your sister's regrets.
BRANDON moves to the door and then stops. He turns to her and speaks with effort.

I have described Mr Willoughby as  the worst of libertines--but I have  since learned from Lady Allen that  he did mean to propose that day.  Therefore I cannot deny that his  intentions towards Marianne were  honourable, and I feel certain he  would have married her, had it not  been for--for the money.
She looks up at BRANDON. Silence.
MARIANNE is sitting on the bed staring into space. ELINOR kneeling by her, holding her hands.
Dearest, was I right to tell you?
Of course.
Whatever his past actions, whatever  his present course, at least you may  be certain that he loved you.
But not enough. Not enough.
ELINOR sits alone with her head in her hands. Suddenly MR JENNINGS hustles in looking pleased.
Here is someone to cheer you up,  Miss Dashwood!
She is followed in by LUCY. MRS JENNINGS leaves, busy as  ever. LUCY plants an expression of ghastly concern on her face.
How is your dear sister, Miss  Dashwood? Poor thing! I must say, I  do not know what I should do if a  man treated me with so little respect.
I hope you are enjoying your stay  with John and Fanny, Miss Steele?
I was never so happy in my entire  life, Miss Dashwood! I do believe  your sister-in-law has taken quite a  fancy to me. I had to come and tell  you--for you cannot imagine what has  happened!
No, I cannot.
Yesterday I was introduced to Edward's  mother!
Indeed?
And she was a vast deal more than  civil. I have not yet seen Edward  but now I feel sure to very soon--
The MAID comes back.
There's a Mr Edward Ferrars to see  you, Miss Dashwood.
There is a tiny frozen silence.
Do ask him to come up.
ELINOR quite involuntarily sits down and then stands up a EDWARD is admitted, looking both anxious and eager. As LU is sitting in the window seat, at first he sees only ELIN
Miss Dashwood, how can I--
But ELINOR cuts him off.
Mr Ferrars, what a pleasure to see  you. You... know Miss Steele, of  course.
EDWARD turns slowly and encounters LUCY's glassy smile. H all but blanches. Then bows, and clears his throat.
How do you do, Miss Steele.
I am well, thank you, Mr Ferrars.
EDWARD has no notion of what to do or say. He swallows.
Do sit down, Mr Ferrars.
LUCY's eyes are sharp as broken glass. EDWARD remains on feet, looking helplessly from one woman to the other.
You must be surprised to find me  here, Mr Ferrars! I expect you thought  I was at your sister's house.
This is precisely what EDWARD had thought. He tries to sm but his facial muscles won't work. ELINOR decides to fetc help.
Let me call Marianne, Mr Ferrars.  She would be most disappointed to  miss you.
ELINOR goes to the door, thankful to escape, but MARIANNE prevents her by walking in at that moment. Despite her  anguish, she is very pleased to see EDWARD and embraces h warmly.
Edward! I heard your voice! At last  you have found us!
EDWARD is shocked by her appearance and momentarily forge his own confusion.
Forgive me, Marianne, my visit is  shamefully overdue. You are pale. I  hope you have not been unwell?
Oh, don't think of me--Elinor is  well, you see, that must be enough  for both of us!
MARIANNE gestures to ELINOR encouragingly but EDWARD seem unable to look at her.
How do you like London, Marianne?
Not at all. The sight of you is all  the pleasure it has afforded, is  that not so, Elinor?

Again, MARIANNE endeavours to ignite the lovers. ELINOR t to silence MARIANNE with her eyes but to no avail. MARIAN puts their coolness down to the presence of LUCY, at whom she glances with a none too friendly air.
Why have you taken so long to come  and see us?
I have been much engaged elsewhere.
Engaged elsewhere! But what was that  when there were such friends to be  met?
Perhaps, Miss Marianne, you think  young men never honour their  engagements, little or great.
ELINOR is appalled by this remark but MARIANNE does not n it and turns back to LUCY earnestly.
No, indeed--for Edward is the most  fearful of giving pain and the most  incapable of being selfish of anyone  I ever saw.
EDWARD makes an uncomfortable noise.
Edward, will you not sit? Elinor,  help me to persuade him.
Now EDWARD can stand it no longer.
Forgive me but I must take my leave--
But you are only just arrived!
ELINOR rises, desperate for them both to go.
You must excuse me, I have a  commission to attend to for Fanny--
LUCY jumps in like a shot.
In that case perhaps you might escort  me back to your sister's house, Mr  Ferrars?
There is an extremely awkward pause.
I would be honoured. Goodbye, Miss  Dashwood, Miss Marianne.

He shakes hands with ELINOR and with MARIANNE, who is sil with dismay. LUCY takes EDWARD's arm and looks up at him  proprietorially. After a stiff bow and a muttered farewell from EDWARD, th leave. MARIANNE looks at her sister in astonishment.
Why did you not urge him to stay?
He must have had his reasons for  going.
His reason was no doubt your coldness.  If I were Edward I would assume you  did not care for me at all.
A tranquil afternoon...
LUCY is sitting with FANNY, who is doing some pointless  basketwork. LUCY hands FANNY rushes.
Poor Miss Marianne looked very badly  t'other day. When I think of her,  deserted and abandoned, it frightens  me to think I shall never marry.
Nonsense. You will marry far better  than either of the Dashwood girls.
How can that possibly be?
You have ten times their sense and  looks.
But I have no dowry.
There are qualities which will always  make up for that, and you have them  in abundance. It would not surprise  me if you were to marry far and away  beyond your expectations.
I wish it might be so. There is a  young man--
Ah ha! I am glad to hear of it. Is  he of good breeding and fortune?
Oh both--but his family would  certainly oppose the match.
Tush! They will allow it as soon as  they see you, my dear.
It is a very great secret. I have  told no one in the world for fear of  discovery.
FANNY looks up, curious to know more.
My dear, I am the soul of discretion.
If I dared tell...
I can assure you I am as silent as  the grave.
LUCY leans forward to whisper in FANNY's ear.
We hold a long shot of the house for a moment of silence. Then from inside comes an almost inhumanly loud shriek.
Viper in my bosom!
FANNY is trying to drag LUCY out of the house. ROBERT and JOHN are trying to reason with her. FANNY loses her grip falls backwards. LUCY flings herself into ROBERT's arms.  ROBERT falls over.
MRS JENNINGS is running as fast as her fat little legs wi carry her.
MRS JENNINGS pants up the front steps.
ELINOR and MARIANNE are packing. Their mood is gloomy and uncommunicative. MRS JENNINGS explodes into the room figh for breath.
Oh, my dears! What a commotion! Mr  Edward Ferrars--the very one I used  to joke you about, Miss Dashwood-- has been engaged these five years to  Lucy Steele!
MARIANNE lets out a gasp. She looks at ELINOR, who nods a her in swift confirmation.

Poor Mr Ferrars! His mother, who by  all accounts is very proud, demanded  that he break the engagement on pain  of disinheritance. But he has refused  to break his promise to Lucy. He has  stood by her, good man, and is cut  off without a penny! She has settled  it all irrevocably upon Mr Robert.  But I cannot stop, I must go to Lucy.  Your sister-in-law scolded her like  any fury--drove her to hysterics.
She leaves the room, still rabbiting on. There is a silen
How long have you known?
Since the evening Mrs Jennings offered  to take us to London.
Why did you not tell me?
Lucy told me in the strictest  confidence.
MARIANNE looks at her in complete incredulity.
I could not break my word.
Clearly, there is no arguing this point.
But Edward loves you.
He made me no promises. He tried to  tell me about Lucy.
He cannot marry her.
Would you have him treat her even  worse than Willoughby has treated  you?
No--but nor would I have him marry  where he does not love.
ELINOR tries hard to be controlled.

Edward made his promise a long time  ago, long before he met me. Though  he may... harbour some regret, I  believe he will be happy--in the  knowledge that he did his duty and  kept his word. After all--after all  that is bewitching in the idea of  one's happiness depending entirely  on one person, it is not always  possible. We must accept. Edward  will marry Lucy--and you and I will  go home.
Always resignation and acceptance!  Always prudence and honour and duty!  Elinor, where is your heart?
ELINOR finally explodes. She turns upon MARIANNE almost  savagely.

What do you know of my heart? What  do you know of anything but your own  suffering? For weeks, Marianne, I  have had this pressing on me without  being at liberty to speak of it to a  single creature. It was forced upon  me by the very person whose prior  claims ruined all my hopes. I have  had to endure her exultation again  and again while knowing myself to be  divided from Edward forever. Believe  me, Marianne, had I not been bound  to silence I could have produced  proof enough of a broken heart even  for you.
Complete silence. Then MARIANNE speaks in a whisper.
Oh, Elinor!
MARIANNE bursts into sobs and flings her arms around ELIN who, almost impatiently, tries to comfort her.

LUCY and MRS JENNINGS are on the doorstep. LUCY looks rat lost and pathetic, with her little bundles, hastily packe The door opens and CHARLOTTE precedes the SERVANT, usheri them in with shrill cries of sympathy.
I have heard that your friend Mr  Ferrars has been entirely cast off  by his family for persevering in his  engagement to Miss Steele.

location: SQUARE IN FRONT OF MRS JENNINGS'S HOUSE

text: ELINOR and BRANDON walk round the quiet square.
Have I been rightly informed? Is it  so?
ELINOR is greatly taken aback by this unexpected query.
It is indeed so. Are you acquainted  with Mr Ferrars?

No, we have never met. But I know  only too well the cruelty--the  impolitic cruelty of dividing two  young people long attached to one  another. Mrs Ferrars does not know  what she may drive her son to--
He pauses, frowning in remembrance. ELINOR waits in suspe
I have a proposal to make that should  enable him to marry Miss Steele  immediately. Since the gentleman is  so close a friend to your family,  perhaps you will be good enough to  mention it to him?
ELINOR is completely taken aback. She takes a moment to r
Colonel, I am sure he would be only  too delighted to hear it from your  own lips.
I think not. His behaviour has proved  him proud--in the best sense. I feel  certain this is the right course.
ELINOR is waiting. The MAID announces EDWARD and he walks momentarily. They are alone for the first time in months for a moment, neither speaks.
Mr Ferrars.
Miss Dashwood.
ELINOR indicates a seat for him but neither sits.
Thank you for responding so promptly  to my message.
I was most grateful to receive it. I-- Miss Dashwood, God knows what you  must think of me...
Mr Ferrars--
He interrupts her, desperate to explain.
I have no right to speak, I know--
ELINOR has to stop him.
Mr Ferrars, I have good news. I think  you know of our friend Colonel  Brandon?
EDWARD looks completely bewildered.
Yes, I have heard his name.
ELINOR starts to speak rather faster than usual.

Colonel Brandon desires me to say  that, understanding you wish to join  the clergy, he has great pleasure in  offering you the parish on his estate  at Delaford, now just vacant, in the  hope that it may enable you--and  Miss Steele--to marry.
EDWARD cannot at first take it in. ELINOR sits down.
Colonel Brandon?
Yes. He means it as testimony of his  concern for--for the cruel situation  in which you find yourselves.
Now EDWARD sits--in shock.
Colonel Brandon give me a parish?  Can it be possible?
The unkindness of your family has  made you astonished to find friendship  elsewhere.
EDWARD looks at ELINOR, his eyes full of growing  comprehension.
No. Not to find it in you. I cannot  be ignorant that to you--to your  goodness--I owe it all. I feel it. I  would express it if I could, but, as  you know, I am no orator.
You are very much mistaken. I assure  you that you owe it almost entirely  to your own merit--I have had no  hand in it.
But EDWARD clearly believes she has been instrumental in offer. He frowns slightly before speaking with rather an  effort.
Colonel Brandon must be a man of  great worth and respect ability.
ELINOR finds some relief in saying at least one thing tha she truly means.
He is the kindest and best of men.
This makes EDWARD seem even more depressed. He sits silen for a moment but then rouses himself to action.
May I enquire why the Colonel did  not tell me himself?
I think he felt it would be better  coming from... a friend.
EDWARD looks at ELINOR, his eyes full of sadness.
Your friendship has been the most  important of my life.
You will always have it.
Forgive me.
Mr Ferrars, you honour your promises-- that is more important than anything  else. I wish you--both--very happy.
They rise. She curtsies. He bows.
Goodbye, Miss Dashwood.
EDWARD leaves silently. ELINOR stands stock-still in the  middle of the room.

The PALMERS' carriage stands outside the house. COLONEL  BRANDON helps MARIANNE in beside ELINOR before mounting h horse to ride alongside. MRS JENNINGS waves goodbye from steps. The carriage moves off. MRS JENNINGS blows her nos looks up and down the street in search of gossip and goes back indoors with a sigh.
MARIANNE is sitting back in her seat with her eyes closed She does not look well. MR PALMER is behind his newspaper

What a stroke of luck for Lucy and  Edward to find a parish so close to  Barton! You will all be able to meet  very often. That will cheer you up,  Miss Marianne. I do declare I have  never disliked a person so much as I  do Mr Willoughby, for your sake.  Insufferable man! To think we can  see his insufferable house from the  top of our hill!
CLOSE on MARIANNE's eyes slowly opening.
I shall ask Jackson to plant some  very tall trees.
(from behind the paper) You will do nothing of the sort.
The carriage bowls along, with BRANDON riding next to it.

I hear Miss Grey's bridal gown was  everything of the finest--made in  Paris, no less. I should have liked  to see it, although I dare say it  was a sorry affair, scalloped with  ruffles--but what do the French know  about fashion?
The carriage stands outside the PALMER residence, a  resplendent affair with a great deal of land. BRANDON is  helping MARIANNE and ELINOR out of the carriage.
I am resolved never to mention Mr  Willoughby's name again, and  furthermore I shall tell everyone I  meet what a good-for nothing he is.
Be quiet.
ELINOR and MARIANNE stand on the steps as the PALMERS deb from the carriage amid a welter of SERVANTS.
(sotto voce) I do not think she drew breath from  the moment we left London. It is my  fault--I should have found some other  way of getting home.
There was no other way you said so  yourself.
We shall be home soon enough. Mamma  will comfort you, dearest.
I am stiff from sitting so long.  Will you tell Charlotte that I am  going for a stroll? ELINOR glances  at the sky in concern.
I think it is going to rain.
No, no, it will not rain.
ELINOR cannot help but smile at this return of the old  MARIANNE.
You always say that and then it always  does.
I will keep to the garden, near the  house.
MARIANNE walks off. ELINOR watches her go anxiously.
MRS BUNTING, a rather baleful NANNY, looks on as MR PALME holds up a screaming BABY in a frilly bonnet for everyone inspection.
We are very proud of our little  Thomas, Colonel--and his papa has  such a way with him...
BRANDON flicks a glance at MR PALMER for whom holding a b comes as naturally as breathing underwater.
MARIANNE walks purposefully towards the garden wall, beyo which lies a hill.
ELINOR enters to find CHARLOTTE alone with the now hyster BABY THOMAS.
There you are, Miss Dashwood! Mr  Palmer and the Colonel have locked  themselves up in the billiard room.  Come and meet little Thomas. Where  is Miss Marianne?
She is taking a little air in the  garden.
Oh, very good. That is the great  advantage of the countryside--all  the fresh air and... and all the  fresh air...
CHARLOTTE's conversational difficulties are drowned out b her offspring.
MARIANNE comes to a gate in the wall and turns the handle It opens. She throws a glance back to the house and passe through. There is a low rumble of thunder.
BABY THOMAS is purple in the face but shows no signs of  quietening. CHARLOTTE joggles him about inefficiently.
(yelling) He is the best child in the world-- he never cries unless he wants to  and then, Lord, there is no stopping  him.
MARIANNE, calm and determined, walks towards the top of t hill. The wind whips and plucks at her hair and skirts.
ELINOR, traumatised by her new acquaintance with the shri BABY THOMAS, goes to look out of the window. She frowns.
ELINOR's POV. MARIANNE is nowhere in sight. Storm clouds  have gathered on the bill.
ELINOR turns from the window. BABY THOMAS stops crying fo two seconds.
I cannot see Marianne.
There is a crack of thunder. BABY THOMAS starts again.
Rain has started to pour down. MARIANNE walks on regardle
CHARLOTTE shouts over BABY THOMAS to ELINOR.
She has probably taken shelter in  one of the greenhouses!

MARIANNE has reached the top. Soaked to the skin, she sta with the storm raging around her, staring at the spires o Combe Magna, the place that would have been her home. Rai streaks her face and the wind whips her hair about her.  Through frozen lips she whispers:
Love is not love Which alters when  it alteration finds Or bends with  the remover to remove: 0, no! it is  an ever-fixed mark That looks on  tempests and is never shaken...
BRANDON is looking for MARIANNE. He enters a greenhouse.
Marianne!
MARIANNE stares at Combe Magna, a strange smile playing a her lips. Then she calls to WILLOUGHBY as though he were  near. The effect is eerie, unworldly.
Willoughby... Willoughby...
CHARLOTTE, MR PALMER and ELINOR are waiting anxiously. BA THOMAS has been removed. ELINOR is staring out of the win
One thing is certain--she will be  wet through when she returns.
Thank you for pointing that out, my  dear. Do not worry, Miss Dashwood-- Brandon will find her. I think we  can all guess where she went.
BRANDON runs up the hillside as though the devil were at heels.
CHARLOTTE is handing ELINOR a cup of tea. ELINOR turns ba to look out of the window. She freezes.
ELINOR's POV of BRANDON walking up to the house with MARI cradled in his arms. It is like seeing Willoughby's ghost
Everyone rushes out of the drawing room as the COLONEL en with MARIANNE. He is exhausted and soaked. MARIANNE is du with cold and fatigue.
She is not hurt--but we must get her  warm!
ELINOR and MR PALMER take MARIANNE from BRANDON and go  upstairs, with CHARLOTTE in pursuit.
The great house sits in darkness. A sense of foreboding.
ELINOR is in her nightgown, knocking at a door. MR PALMER answers in his nightshirt, astonished to have been summon out of bed.
I think Marianne may need a doctor.
MR PALMER and CHARLOTTE are sitting at the breakfast tabl BRANDON is pacing. The rain has stopped.
You'll wear yourself out, Colonel!  Do not worry! A day or two in bed  will soon set her to rights!
You can rely upon Harris, Colonel. I  have never found a better physician.
Enter ELINOR with DR HARRIS.
(urgent) What is your diagnosis?
It is an infectious fever that has  taken far more serious hold than I  would have expected in one so young.  I would recommend the hasty removal  of your child, Mr Palmer--
CHARLOTTE runs out of the room screaming.
Mrs Bunting! Mrs Bunting!
CHARLOTTE is getting into their carriage with MRS BUNTING and BABY THOMAS. MR PALMER is on the steps with ELINOR. H takes her hand and looks at her with real sympathy.
My dear Miss Dashwood, I am more  sorry than I can say. If you would  prefer me to stay I am at your  service.
ELINOR is touched to find this warm heart beneath his fro exterior.
Mr Palmer, that is very kind. But  Colonel Brandon and Dr Harris will  look after us. Thank you for  everything you have done.
MR PALMER nods, presses her hand, and walks down the step to the carriage.
BRANDON sits head in hands. His ghosts have come to haunt him.
MARIANNE is tossing and turning in the bed. DR HARRIS is  trying to take her pulse. He looks up at ELINOR, who is  watching anxiously.
She is not doing as well as I would  like.
ELINOR exits the bedroom to find BRANDON outside. She jum
What can I do?
Colonel, you have done so much  already.
Give me an occupation, Miss Dashwood,  or I shall run mad. He is dangerously  quiet.
She would be easier if her mother  were here.
Of course. Barton is but eight hours  away. If I make no stop, you may see  us early tomorrow morning.
He takes ELINOR's hand and kisses it.
In your hands I know she will be  safe.
BRANDON mounts his horse, turns to look at the house for moment, and then spurs it violently forward.
ELINOR is by the window, having watched BRANDON's departu DR HARRIS is by MARIANNE's side. He turns to ELINOR.
Double the number of drops and I  will return as soon as I can.
The house stands in virtual darkness with only a dim ligh issuing from one of the upper rooms.
BRANDON riding fast, his cape billowing out behind him.
MARIANNE's eyes glitter with the fever. ELINOR wipes her  brow. Suddenly she speaks.
Who is that?
She is looking at the end of the bed.
Look, look, Elinor.
There is no one there, dearest.
It is Papa. Papa has come.
ELINOR looks fearfully towards the end of the bed. MARIAN tries to smile with her cracked lips.
Dearest Papa!
The dead are coming for the dying.
ELINOR, her eyes red from watching, wipes MARIANNE's temp DR HARRIS takes her pulse and looks at ELINOR anxiously. silence is worse than any utterance.
The room is very still. MARIANNE is pale as wax. DR HARRI puts on his coat. ELINOR looks at him fearfully.
I must fetch more laudanum. I cannot  pretend, Miss Dashwood, that your  sister's condition is not very  serious. You must prepare yourself.  I will return very shortly.
He leaves the room.
MARIANNE lies in the grip of her fever. ELINOR sits watch her. Slowly she rises and walks to the bed. When she spea her tone is very practical.
Marianne, Marianne, please try--
Suddenly, almost unconsciously, she starts to heave with sobs, wrenched out of her, full of anguish and heartbreak and all the more painful for being tearless.
Marianne, please try--I cannot--I  cannot do without you. Oh, please, I  have tried to bear everything else-- I will try--but please, dearest,  beloved Marianne, do not leave me  alone.
She falls to her knees by the bed, gulping for breath, ta MARIANNE's hand and kissing it again and again.
A shimmer of light appears on the rim of the horizon.  Somewhere a lark breaks into clear untroubled song.

DR HARRIS sits slumped in a chair. MARIANNE lies motionle ELINOR rises with difficulty from the bedside and goes to the window. She is white as paper. The lark sings. Then,  from behind, comes the faintest of whispers.
Elinor?
ELINOR turns with a cry. DR HARRIS springs from his seat examines MARIANNE. He then turns to ELINOR with a smile o relief and nods. At that moment the sound of carriage whe is heard on the gravel.
My mother!
BRANDON helps MRS DASHWOOD, who is weak with exhaustion a distress, out of the carriage.
ELINOR hurls herself down the stairs. She reaches the doo just as BRANDON and MRS DASHWOOD enter and practically sw into her mother's arms.
Mamma! She is out of danger!
CLOSE on MARIANNE's face as MRS DASHWOOD kisses her.
There, there, my love, my Marianne.
MARIANNE opens her eyes and smiles at her mother. MRS DAS takes her gently into her arms. MARIANNE suddenly looks  anxious. She is too weak to move her head. She whispers w urgent effort.
Where is Elinor?
I am here, dearest, I am here.
MARIANNE looks at her with deep relief. Behind the DASHWO BRANDON stands at the door, unwilling to intrude on this  intimacy. He wipes his eyes and turns away. MARIANNE sees and whispers to him.
Colonel Brandon.
BRANDON turns back, his eyes full of tears. MARIANNE look at him for a moment. Then, very quietly:
Thank you.

The cottage nestles in the first buds of spring. A piece rope hangs down from the branches of a tree in the garden It starts to wave about wildly and we see MARGARET emergi and climbing down. She has built herself a new tree-house
What though the sea with waves  continuall Doe eate the earth, it is  no more at all.
MARIANNE is on the sofa by the window. She is pale,  convalescent and calm. Different somehow. She listens int as BRANDON reads her the poem.
Nor is the earth the lesse, or loseth  aught. For whatsoever from one place  doth fall, Is with the tide unto  another brought...
We move back to find MRS DASHWOOD and ELINOR at the other end of the room, sewing peacefully.
He certainly is nor so dashing as  Willoughby but he has a far more  pleasing countenance. There was always  a something, if you remember, in  Willoughby's eyes at times which I  did not like.
ELINOR listens patiently as her mother rewrites history. cut back to BRANDON as he finishes reading.
'For there is nothing lost, but may  be found, if sought...
He looks up at MARIANNE. A soul-breathing glance. She smi as he closes the book.
Shall we continue tomorrow?
No--for I must away.
Away? Where?
(teasing) That I cannot tell you. It is a  secret.
He rises to leave.
(impulsive) But you will not stay away long?
CLOSE on BRANDON's reaction.
ELINOR and MARIANNE are out on a walk. They go very slowl MARIANNE leaning on ELINOR's arm. Their mood is loving,  companion able.
ELINOR and MARIANNE walk on. Suddenly, MARIANNE stops.
There.
She indicates a spot on the ground but ELINOR can see not and is momentarily alarmed. MARIANNE gazes at the ground breathes in deeply.
There I fell, and there I first saw  Willoughby.
Poor Willoughby. He will always regret  you.
But does it follow that, had he chosen  me, he would have been content?
ELINOR looks at MARIANNE, surprised.
He would have had a wife he loved  but no money--and might soon have  learned to rank the demands of his  pocket-book far above the demands of  his heart.
ELINOR regards MARIANNE admiringly. MARIANNE smiles sadly
If his present regrets are half as  painful as mine, he will suffer  enough.
Do you compare your conduct with  his?
No. I compare it with what it ought  to have been. I compare it with yours.
Our situations were very different.
My illness has made me consider the  past. I saw in my own behaviour  nothing but imprudence--and worse. I  was insolent and unjust to everyone--
ELINOR tries to stem the flow but MARIANNE continues.

--but you--you I wronged above all.  Only I knew your heart and its sorrows  but even then I was never a grain  more compassionate. I brought my  illness upon myself--I wanted to  destroy myself. And had I succeeded,  what misery should I have caused  you?
ELINOR embraces her. They stand with their arms round one another in silence for a moment. Then MARIANNE breaks awa and speaks with great good humour and energy.

I shall mend my ways! I shall no  longer worry others nor torture  myself. I am determined to enter on  a course of serious study---Colonel  Brandon has promised me the run of  his library and I shall read at least  six hours a day. By the end of the  year I expect to have improved my  learning a very great deal.
THOMAS is sitting on the back of a local wagon, holding a basket of food. He jumps off near the cottage and waves a cheery farewell the DRIVER.

CLOSE on the accounts book, covered in blots and crossed- sums. Pull up to reveal MARIANNE labouring over it. Her  sickness has left her slightly short-sighted and she uses pince-nez that makes her look like an owl. ELINOR is sewing and MRS DASHWOOD is snoozing. MARGARET g up and looks over MARIANNE's shoulder. She frowns at the  spider's web of ink.
You'll go blind if you're not careful.
BETSY brings in coals for the fire. MRS DASHWOOD rouses  herself.
Is Thomas back from Exeter, Betsy?
Yes, ma'am--he brung back two lovely  fillets for you.
MRS DASHWOOD looks nervously at ELINOR like a child who h been caught out.
Beef is far less expensive in Exeter,  and anyway they are for Marianne.
ELINOR laughs and rolls her eyes to heaven. BETSY turns o her way out to remark:
Sixpence a piece, Miss Dashwood. Oh,  and he says Mr Ferrars is married,  but I suppose you know that, ma'am.
There is a stunned silence. Everyone looks at ELINOR.
Fetch Thomas to us, Betsy.
BETSY leaves. They all sit very still. MARGARET is about talk to ELINOR about it but MARIANNE stops her. THOMAS en
Beg pardon, Miss Dashwood, but they  was the cheapest in the market--
It was a very good price, Thomas,  well done. Would you be so kind as  to build up the fire a little?
(relieved) Yes, ma'am.
There is a pause.
Who told you that Mr Ferrars was  married, Thomas?
THOMAS builds up the fire as he answers. He tells the sto with pleasure.

I seen him myself, ma'am, and his  lady too, Miss Lucy Steele as was-- they were stopping in a chaise at  the New London Inn. I happened to  look up as I passed the chaise and I  see it was Miss Steele. So I took  off my hat and she inquired after  you, ma'am, and all the young ladies,  especially Miss Dashwood, and bid me  I should give you her and Mr Ferrars's  best compliments and service and how  they'd be sure to send you a piece  of the cake.
Was Mr Ferrars in the carriage with  her?
Yes, ma'am--I just seen him leaning  back in it, but he did not look up.
ELINOR screws up her courage.
Did--
But she cannot continue. MARIANNE glances at her  compassionately and takes over.
Did Mrs Ferrars seem well?
Yes, Miss Marianne--she said how she  was vastly contented and, since she  was always a very affable young lady,  I made free to wish her joy.
Thank you, Thomas.
He nods and leaves, confused by the silent atmosphere. EL sits for a moment, then gets up and walks out.
ELINOR is standing by the gate, looking out. MRS DASHWOOD comes down the path to join her. She links arms with ELIN and they stand in silence for a beat.
Your father once told me not to allow  you to neglect yourself. Now I find  that it is I who have neglected you  most.
No, Mamma.
Yes, I have. We all have. Marianne  is right.
I am very good at hiding.
Then we must observe you more closely.
A pause.
Mamma?
Yes, my darling?
There is a painful difference between  the expectation of an unpleasant  event and its final certainty.
MRS DASHWOOD squeezes ELINOR's arm tightly.
A horse and cart are jogging along. The cart contains a l object tied down and covered with canvas. The DRIVER whis tunelessly.
MARGARET is standing on the kitchen table while ELINOR an MARIANNE pin a piece of material around the bottom of her skirt to lengthen it. Suddenly there is a commotion upstairs.
Marianne! Marianne! Come and see  what is coming!
Everyone runs out of the kitchen.
THOMAS and the CARTER are carrying a small piano up the p
They carry the piano into the parlour and to the DASHWOOD joyful astonishment it fits perfectly. MRS DASHWOOD reads out the letter that has accompanied it.

'At last I have found a small enough  instrument to fir the parlour. I  expect to follow it in a day or two,  by which time I expect you to have  learned the enclosed. Your devoted  friend, Christopher Brandon.'
MRS DASHWOOD hands MARIANNE the letter and a broadsheet s
He must like you very much, Marianne.
It is not just for me! It is for all  of us.
All the same, she looks conscious of the truth.

MARGARET is up her tree. ELINOR is pulling weeds. MRS DAS is sitting on a stool working on MARGARET's dress and  listening to the strains of the new song which MARIANNE i singing in the cottage. All of a sudden, MRS DASHWOOD ris shielding her eyes with her hand. She walks down to the g looking out.
Here is Colonel Brandon! Marianne!
The piano stops. MARIANNE comes out and they all gather a the gate to watch for the rider.
Their POV of a HORSEMAN in the distance.
I do not think it is the Colonel.
It must be. He said he would arrive  today. You must play him the new  song, Marianne.
Suddenly there is a yell from MARGARET's tree.
Edward!
MARGARET practically throws herself out of the tree onto grass.
It is Edward!
The women look at each other in complete consternation.
Calm. We must be calm.
Tense silence reigns. Everyone tries to busy themselves.  BETSY enters.
Mr Ferrars for you, ma'am.
EDWARD follows her in, looking white and agitated.
(rising) Edward! What a pleasure to see you.
Mrs Dashwood. Miss Marianne. Margaret.  Miss Dashwood. I hope I find you all  well.
He bows formally to each of them, lingering on ELINOR, wh is looking firmly at her lap. He looks anxious.
Thank you, Edward, we are all very  well.
There is a pause while they all search for an appropriate remark. Finally MARGARET decides to have a go at polite  conversation.
We have been enjoying very fine  weather.
MARIANNE looks at her incredulously.
Well, we have.
I am glad of it. The... the roads  were very dry.
MRS DASHWOOD decides to bite the bullet.
(giving him her hand) May I wish you great joy, Edward.
He takes her hand somewhat confusedly and accepts her off of a seat. There is an awful silence. MARIANNE tries to h
I hope you have left Mrs Ferrars  well?
Tolerably, thank you.
There is another bone-crunching pause.
I--But EDWARD cannot seem to find  any words.
Is Mrs Ferrars at the new parish?
EDWARD looks extremely confused.
No--my mother is in town.
He plucks up the courage to look at ELINOR again and is  evidently not much comforted by what he sees.
I meant to enquire after Mrs Edward  Ferrars.
EDWARD colours. He hesitates.
Then you have not heard--the news--I  think you mean my brother--you mean  Mrs Robert Ferrars.
They all stare at him in shock.
Mrs Robert Ferrars?
ELINOR has frozen. EDWARD rises and goes to the window.

Yes. I received a letter from Miss  Steele--or Mrs Ferrars, I should say-- communicating the... the transfer of  her affections to my brother Robert.  They were much thrown together in  London, I believe, and... and in  view of the change in my  circumstances, I felt it only fair  that Miss Steele be released from  our engagement. At any rate, they  were married last week and are now  in Plymouth.
ELINOR rises suddenly, EDWARD turns and they stand lookin at one another.
Then you--are not married.
No.

ELINOR bursts into tears. The shock of this emotional  explosion stuns everyone for a second and then MARIANNE m an executive decision. Wordlessly, she takes MARGARET's h and leads her and MRS DASHWOOD out of the room.
The three DASHWOODS come into the garden, still holding h
ELINOR cannot stop crying. EDWARD comes forward, very slo

Elinor! I met Lucy when I was very  young. Had I had an active profession,  I should never have felt such an  idle, foolish inclination. At Norland  my behaviour was very wrong. But I  convinced myself you felt only  friendship for me and it was my heart  alone that I was risking. I have  come with no expectations. Only to  profess, now that I am at liberty to  do so, that my heart is and always  will be yours.
ELINOR looks at him, her face streaked with tears of rele emotion, of pain and of happiness.
MARIANNE and MRS DASHWOOD are stamping about in the garde trying to keep warm. MARGARET has climbed into her tree-h The branches rustle.
He's sitting next to her!
Margaret, come down!/Is he?
(scolding) Margaret! Will you stop--
What's happening now?
Marianne!
He's kneeling down!
MRS DASHWOOD can't help herself.
Oh! Is he? Oh!
She and MARIANNE look at each other joyfully.
The figures of EDWARD and ELINOR can be seen walking, in  deep conversation.
Later. The lovers walk slowly, their heads almost touchin their words low and intimate.
Your mother, I suppose, will hardly  be less angry with Robert for marrying  Lucy.
The more so since she settled the  money upon him so irrevocably--
--no doubt because she had run out  of sons to disinherit.

Her family fluctuates at an alarming  rate. Then, in London, when you told  me of the Colonel's offer, I became  convinced that you wanted me to marry  Lucy and that--well, that you and  Colonel Brandon...
Me and Colonel Brandon!
I shall not forget attempting to  thank him for making it possible for  me to marry the woman I did not love  while convinced he had designs upon  the woman I did--do--love.
EDWARD stops walking. He looks at ELINOR and realises he stand it no longer.
Would you--can you--excuse me--
He takes her face in his hands and kisses her.
A group of VILLAGE CHILDREN run down the hillside towards the church waving ribbons and dressed in their Sunday bes

A large wedding party is gathered outside the church. The entire village is present--CHILDREN, FARMERS, LABOURERS,  SHOPKEEPERS, and all our PRINCIPALS. We see MRS JENNINGS a gigantic mauve bonnet, CHARLOTTE and MR PALMER, SIR JOH MRS DASHWOOD, MARGARET, THOMAS, JOHN and FANNY, who is dr in a fantastically inappropriate concoction, and some MEN regimental uniform. The path to the church is strewn with wild flowers and  everyone holds a bunch of their own. The church bells sta to peal, and a great cheer goes up as the door opens and  BETSY comes out holding the bridal cake aloft. The bride and groom appear: MARIANNE, in white lawn, and  COLONEL BRANDON in full uniform. Behind them come EDWARD his parson's garb and, on his arm, ELINOR as matron of ho CLOSE on them as they watch the party moving away. MARIAN and BRANDON make their way forwards, everyone throws thei flowers over them, whooping and singing. An open carriage decked with bridal wreaths comes to meet them, and BRANDO lifts MARIANNE in.
